_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The Bama Foods, LTD. facility abides by the emergency response procedures and policies detailed in the Bama Safety Plan manual.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1)  To save lives.
2)  To minimize and avoid injuries.
3)  To protect the environment.
4)  To minimize property damage.

Bama Foods, LTD. maintains an emergency response team whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the OSHA PSM Standard and the EPA RMP Rule, as well as to incorporate any facility and personnel changes. 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
The Bama Foods, LTD. facility prepares frozen bakery products for distribution.  The facility utilizes an industrial refrigeration system in order to conduct operations, and ammonia is used in the system uses ammonia as a refrigerant. The system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for process equipment and cold storage rooms. Typical operating conditions range from vacuum (approximately 9 Hg) on the low pressure side of the system to 180-200 psig on the high side.

Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the refrigeration process.  The total ammonia inventory is 54,000 pounds.  

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
In order to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility has developed an accidental release prevention program t

hat complies with the following regulations:

1)  OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard; and
2)  EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule.

The program is comprised of several elements geared towards the prevention of an accidental release of ammonia and ensuring the safety of employees and the surrounding community.

In addition to implementing the program, Bama Foods, LTD. follows recognized standards and good engineering practices using state and local codes and IIAR standards for operating and maintaining the ammonia refrigeration system.  The system has been designed with several safety features to prevent a release of ammonia.  For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  The facility has also installed ammonia sensors throughout the facility which will alert plant personnel in the event of an ammonia detection.

Five Year Accident History
A review of the facility's five year accident history showed that there have been no incidents at the facility that meet the RMP criteria for a reportable accident (onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place).  In addition, there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds.  

Within the course of the last five years, the facility has experienced small ammonia leaks from the system, however none of these incidents meet the criteria discussed above.  As required, these incidents are investigated following the procedures of the Incident Investigation program to determine the root cause of the leak and any contributing factors.  Corre

ctive actions are devised and implemented to prevent recurrence of these incidents.
		
Emergency Response Program
Bama Foods, LTD. has an Emergency Response Program, which includes procedures for responding to ammonia releases and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite.  The facility has an Emergency Response Team that is trained throughout the year.  All Emergency Response Team members receive HAZWOPER training and are fit tested and respiratory trained annually.   

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Bama Foods, LTD. has worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to provide a safe work environment for its employees. A Compliance Audit was conducted on December 11, 2020, and the PHA was revalidated on April 4, 2018.  Recommendations were generated as a result of these analyses to improve safety at the facility. All recommendations from the 2018 PHA Revalidation have been completed. The facility is working on addressing the open action items from the 2020 Compliance Audit
